intro.heading: Introduction
intro.summary: The paper reviews published human alleles with protective effects against cancer and promoting bone, muscle, and cardiovascular health, relevant to aerospace medicine. Omics technologies are being used to develop health recommendations, but these alleles have not been systematically characterized for spaceflight. Deep space exploration broadens human diversity in space, necessitating precision healthcare and countermeasures, with omics potentially improving health maintenance in space. The study considers challenges and ethics of researching protective mechanisms for space crew health during extended missions.

figures.caption: Fig.3| Literature review of evidence for protective alleles.Literature review and its key findings for a subset of alleles that may be linked to health protective effects, many of which occur naturally in the human population.From

sections.heading: Spaceflight Health Risk Countermeasures
sections.summary: Spaceflight induces physiological stress, affecting musculoskeletal, cardiovascular, and other systems, increasing cancer, diabetes, and aging risks. Known alleles impacting radiation tolerance, bone density, and immune function may benefit from precision countermeasures, though adaptation has limits. Omics aids understanding of risks to improve traditional protective measures. Aerospace healthcare programs should integrate omics data. Figure 2 illustrates spaceflight health risks, countermeasures, and benefiting terrestrial populations; examples include musculoskeletal, cardiovascular, cancer, diabetes, sleep, and vision-related risks.

sections.heading: Space-Induced Radiation Syndrome And Cancer Threat
sections.summary: Radiation exposure poses in-flight (acute radiation sickness) and long-term (cancer) health hazards during deep space missions. ISS astronauts receive lower radiation doses due to Earth's magnetosphere, unlike deep space missions. A 500-day Mars mission could expose astronauts to career radiation limits, increasing cancer risk. Models suggest higher cancer risks from Mars missions than previously estimated. Other celestial bodies pose even greater dangers.

sections.heading: Space-Induced Bone Demineralization
sections.summary: LEO studies show monthly bone mineral density (BMD) loss of 1-1.5% in weight-bearing bones. Six-month ISS missions cause bone loss equivalent to two decades of aging. Models predict 32.4-36.8% BMD loss during Mars missions, leading to osteopenia, osteoporosis, and fracture risks. Deep space radiation exacerbates BMD loss. Recovered bone after spaceflight resembles that of older individuals. Upcoming missions lasting over a year intensify concerns.

sections.heading: Studying Omics For Improved Spaceflight Safety
sections.summary: Published alleles with protective mechanisms relevant to spaceflight healthcare exist, potentially overlapping with nutrition and exercise interventions. Research into these alleles may improve therapeutics and recommendations for deep space crew health. Technical and ethical challenges complicate basic scientific research into these alleles' protective mechanisms. Figure 3 presents a literature review of evidence for protective alleles.

sections.heading: Human Cohorts Reveal Protective Alleles
sections.summary: Alleles with protective mechanisms were discovered by studying special human cohorts. For example, a toddler with a myostatin mutation had gross muscle hypertrophy. Families revealed genes for stronger bones (LRP5) and higher oxygen transport (EPOR). Isolated populations showed alleles linked to alleviated atherosclerosis and cancer. Populations adapted to extreme environments offer insights into altered gas composition tolerance. These findings inform potential spaceflight countermeasures.

sections.heading: Omics For Improved Spaceflight Nutrition
sections.summary: Omics-based nutritional counseling benefits individuals with specific genetic variants. Genetic variants modify responses to nutrients like vitamins and fats, influencing immunity, organ health, endurance, and skills. Omics can inform nutrition during space exploration, exemplified by spaceflight-associated neuro-ocular syndrome (SANS) linked to vitamin B levels and one-carbon metabolism genes. Dietary interventions related to alleles could counteract space-induced inflammation, such as plant polyphenols activating SIRT1.

sections.heading: Pharmacogenomics And Optimized Drug Prescribing
sections.summary: Spaceflight pharmacogenomics (SPGx) studies gene variants influencing drug metabolism in space, impacting safety and efficacy. Many drug-gene combinations exist in terrestrial medicine with pharmacogenomics-guided recommendations. Statin-induced myopathy exemplifies SPGx relevance to spaceflight, where muscle loss is a challenge.

sections.heading: Technical And Ethical Challenges Of Studying Space Omics

conclusion: Researching protective alleles can improve space crew health and potentially benefit those in stressful environments on Earth. Despite technical and ethical challenges, further investigation into these mechanisms can lead to better nutrition, exercise, and health recommendations, promoting a more inclusive and safe future for space exploration.

_meta.paper_title: Protective alleles and precision healthcare in crewed spaceflight
